key_points: Global COVID-19 death toll surpassed 5 million, signaling a devastating milestone in the pandemic.
US, EU, Britain, and Brazil account for nearly half of all reported deaths despite being high-income countries.
COVID-19 is the third leading cause of death globally, after heart disease and stroke.
The actual death toll is likely higher due to limited testing and unreported at-home deaths.
Eastern Europe, particularly Russia and Ukraine, currently among the hardest hit due to vaccination challenges.
Wealthier nations with older populations have been particularly vulnerable, while poorer countries with younger demographics have fared better.
Wealth disparities within countries reveal poorer neighborhoods suffering the most.
Global vaccination efforts exhibit inequality, with rich countries beginning booster shots while Africa lags behind.
United Nations labels the failure to adequately vaccinate the world as a 'global shame'.
Personal stories from around the world illustrate the profound and varied impact COVID-19 has had on individuals and families.
spokespersons: Dr. Albert Ko (Infectious Disease Specialist, Yale School of Public Health)
Dr. Wafaa El-Sadr (Director, ICAP, Columbia University)
